results.title: The Japanese Author Behind ‘Bullet Train’ Is OK That the Film Isn’t So Japanese
results.abstract: Kotaro Isaka dreamed that his novel would get the big-screen treatment. Now it’s an action thriller starring Brad Pitt. Does the lack of major Asian stars matter?

multimedia.caption: With the release of the action thriller “Bullet Train,” based on his novel, the work of Kotaro Isaka may become better known in the West.
multimedia.copyright: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

results.title: B.J. Novak Went to Texas Looking for ‘Vengeance’ and Found America
results.abstract: The first film from a former star of “The Office” is a dark comedy about life in a nation that’s not as divided as we might think.

multimedia.caption: “I thought that these huge dudes with beards and pickup trucks would be very suspicious of a Hollywood blue-state guy, and I found the exact opposite,” B.J. Novak said of his research trips to Texas.
multimedia.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

results.abstract: With a face that launched a thousand GIFs, the actress is bringing her expressive range to “Nope,” Jordan Peele’s latest social thriller.

results.title: Rediscovering Australia’s Generation of Defiant Female Directors
results.abstract: Gillian Armstrong, Jane Campion, Essie Coffey and others had waited years to tell their stories, as a Museum of the Moving Image series shows.

multimedia.caption: Judy Davis in “My Brilliant Career,” screening in the series Pioneering Women in Australian Cinema.

results.title: Study Shows Disability Representation Onscreen Is Increasing, but Still Falls Short
results.abstract: The study published Tuesday also showed that television continues to lag behind film when it comes to representation of characters with disabilities.

results.title: Paul Sorvino: A Voluble Man Who Excelled as a Brick of a Mobster
results.abstract: The actor may be best known for “Goodfellas,” but he almost bailed on it because the character of the underboss Paulie Cicero was so difficult to pin down.

multimedia.caption: Paul Sorvino as the mob underboss who gave orders with just a nod of his head in “Goodfellas.”
Paul Sorvino as the mob underboss who gave orders with just a nod of his head in “Goodfellas.”
Paul Sorvino as the mob underboss who gave orders with just a nod of his head in “Goodfellas.”

results.title: Bob Rafelson, Director of ‘Five Easy Pieces,’ Dies at 89
results.abstract: A central figure in the New Hollywood movement, he was also the co-creator of the TV pop group the Monkees and featured it in a movie, “Head.”

multimedia.caption: The director Bob Rafelson in 1987. A skilled navigator of the rapidly shifting pop-culture landscape of the 1960s, he was a producer of “Easy Rider.”
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Doris Thomas/Fairfax Media via Getty Images

results.title: ‘Nope,’ Eadweard Muybridge and the Story of ‘The Horse in Motion’
results.abstract: Is the rider in the 19th-century photographic experiments really unknown, as Jordan Peele’s film implies? It’s complicated.

multimedia.caption: Known as “Plate Number 626,” this Eadweard Muybridge study of a horse in motion is a key element of “Nope.”
multimedia.copyright: Eadweard Muybridge, via National Gallery of Art

results.title: How to Find the One
results.abstract: After swooning at the interracial couple in “Bend It Like Beckham,” she knew how she wanted her romantic life to unfold. But the future had other plans.

results.title: Why Brandon Perea’s ‘Nope’ Audition Made Jordan Peele Cry
results.abstract: The actor’s unexpected take on Angel, the Fry’s worker, so won over the director that he decided during their meeting to rewrite the script.

multimedia.caption: Perea said the dialogue he was handed for his “Nope” audition depicted Angel as a happy, up worker. “I was like, ‘Hmm, you don’t see that when you go into an electronics store. The employees do not want to be there.’”
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Perea said the dialogue he was handed for his “Nope” audition depicted Angel as a happy, up worker. “I was like, ‘Hmm, you don’t see that when you go into an electronics store. The employees do not want to be there.’”

results.title: Paul Sorvino, Master of the Mild-Mannered Mobster, Dies at 83
results.abstract: A would-be singing star, he found success in Hollywood playing a variety of roles, but they were often quiet, dangerous men, like Paulie Cicero in “Goodfellas.”

multimedia.caption: Paul Sorvino in 1976. He sang and performed onstage before finding his stride in movies and television.

results.abstract: The studio announced news of the film’s release on Saturday at the pop-culture convention Comic-Con International in San Diego.

results.title: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
results.abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.

multimedia.caption: The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.
The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.
The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.

results.title: ‘The Reverend’ Review: A Beer With a Music Chaser

results.title: ‘My Old School’ Review: An Impostor Makes the Honor Roll
results.abstract: A documentary uses animation and professional actors to tell the story of a once-notorious hoax.

multimedia.caption: In “My Old School,” part of the tale is lip-synced by the actor Alan Cumming, using the voice of an interview subject who does not appear on camera.

results.title: ‘My Donkey, My Lover & I’ Review: Three’s a Crowd
results.abstract: In this idiosyncratic comedy from France, a besotted schoolteacher crashes her married lover’s hiking trip and befriends a deeply opinionated donkey.

results.title: Nolan Ryan Had a Softer Side. He Just Hid It (Very) Well.
results.abstract: A new documentary explores the unique challenge of facing Ryan, the game’s most prolific strikeout artist, but also shows off a gentler version of the Ryan Express.

multimedia.caption: Even in an era full of strikeouts and no-hitters, Nolan Ryan’s legend endures. He still holds 51 records, by his count.

results.abstract: Jordan Peele’s genre-melting third feature stars Daniel Kaluuya and Keke Palmer as brother-and-sister horse wranglers defending the family ranch from an extraterrestrial threat.

results.title: ‘Boomerang’ at 30: Think of It as the Robin Givens Rom-Com
results.abstract: It’s remembered as Eddie Murphy’s bid at romantic stardom and as a key point in Halle Berry’s career. But the riveting antagonist arguably created a new archetype.

results.title: What to Know About Jafar Panahi, the Imprisoned Iranian Filmmaker
results.abstract: The auteur is now serving a sentence that Iran’s judiciary handed down in 2010 when he was arrested for supporting protests.

results.title: For a Revered Art House Cinema, a Season of Off Screen Turmoil
results.abstract: The Jacob Burns Film Center in Westchester, a celebrated venue that enjoys backing from cinema’s A-list, has been roiled by the dismissal of one of its original leaders who was accused of bullying behavior.

multimedia.caption: The Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, N.Y., a successful art house theater that has drawn support from many of cinema’s most talented actors and directors.

results.title: In a New Take on ‘Gaslight,’ a Heroine Finds Her Own Way
results.abstract: At this year’s Shaw Festival in Ontario, a favorite melodrama is reimagined, and other plays grapple with femininity and gender fluidity.

results.title: Why Is It So Hard to Adapt Austen? The Fans Play a Part.
results.abstract: The backlash to the Netflix version of “Persuasion” has as much to do with who’s watching as who’s scripting. Still, the new film broke some rules.

results.title: Quidditch Becomes ‘Quadball,’ Leaving J.K. Rowling Behind
results.abstract: Citing trademark concerns and objections to the author’s views on transgender issues, the sport’s leading groups officially distanced themselves from their “Harry Potter” roots.
